rev.diff:
Line 83: Line 83:
===Future of Windows===
===Future of Windows===
[[File:Windows 8 Developer Preview Start Screen.png|thumb|250px|Screenshot of Windows 8 startscreen]]
[[File:Windows 8 Developer Preview Start Screen.png|thumb|250px|Screenshot of Windows 8 startscreen]]
â
[[File:Windows To Go USB Flash Drive.png|thumb|Bootable [[Windows To Go]] USB flash drive|link=Windows To Go]]
 
[[Windows 8]], the successor to Windows 7, is currently in development. Microsoft posted a blog entry in Dutch on October 22, 2010 hinting that Windows 8 would be released in 2 years.<ref>{{cite news |title=Microsoft says Windows 8 roughly two years away |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13860_3-20020544-56.html?tag=mncol;title |work=CNET News |publisher=CNET |date=October 24, 2010 |accessdate=December 9, 2010}}</ref> Also, during the pre-[[Consumer Electronics Show]] keynote, [[Microsoft]]'s [[CEO]] announced that Windows 8 will also run on [[ARM Architecture|ARM]] [[CPU]]s. This Windows version will also be more suitable for [[Tablet personal computer|tablet]]s and netbooks, featuring a more touch-friendly interface. Several new features will also be introduced, such as support for USB 3.0 and the ability to run Windows from USB devices (like USB Hard Disks or USB Flash drives) with [[Windows To Go]].
[[Windows 8]], the successor to Windows 7, is currently in development. Microsoft posted a blog entry in Dutch on October 22, 2010 hinting that Windows 8 would be released in 2 years.<ref>{{cite news |title=Microsoft says Windows 8 roughly two years away |url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-13860_3-20020544-56.html?tag=mncol;title |work=CNET News |publisher=CNET |date=October 24, 2010 |accessdate=December 9, 2010}}</ref> Also, during the pre-[[Consumer Electronics Show]] keynote, [[Microsoft]]'s [[CEO]] announced that Windows 8 will also run on [[ARM Architecture|ARM]] [[CPU]]s. This Windows version will also be more suitable for [[Tablet personal computer|tablet]]s and netbooks, featuring a more touch-friendly interface. Several new features will also be introduced, such as support for USB 3.0 and the ability to run Windows from USB devices (like USB Hard Disks or USB Flash drives) with [[Windows To Go]].
